      • forString

        public static Argument<java.lang.Void> forString(@Nonnull
                                                 java.lang.String arg)
        Create an Argument that just match a specific string. Automatically escape special characters.
        Parameters:
        arg - The string to match to.
        Returns:
        An new Argument already registered.

      • registerArguments

        public static void registerArguments(@Nonnull
                                     java.lang.Class<?> clazz)
        Register Argument constants in a class so they can be retrieve by their name. They must be declared as above, with the public and static modifiers and the RegisterArgument annotation.
        Parameters:
        clazz - The class that contains the fields to register.

      • registerArgument

        public static void registerArgument(@Nonnull
                                    java.lang.String name,
                                    @Nonnull
                                    Argument argument)
        Register an Argument with the given name.
        Parameters:
        name - The name of the argument used to identify it.
        argument - The argument to register.

      • getArgument

        @Nullable
public static Argument<?> getArgument(@Nonnull
                                                 java.lang.String name)
        Query a registered argument.
        Parameters:
        name - The name of the argument (the name of the static field where it come from).
        Returns:
        An possibly-null Argument.

      • getArgument

        @Nonnull
public static <T> Argument<? super T> getArgument(@Nonnull
                                                            java.lang.Class<T> clazz,
                                                            @Nullable
                                                            java.lang.String indication)
                                                     throws InvalidCommandPatternMethodException
        Query a registered argument by its type. If there is more that one argument for this type, the closest from the real type is chosen ex: If Integer is queried and Number and Integer are available, Integer will be chosen. If there is equivalent choices the indication is used and the name of the argument is matched (actually it uses a String.startsWith(String)) to determinate the right choice. THE INDICATION IS USED AS A LAST RESORT. If the ambiguity is still here, an exception is thrown. If the target is of type Void, the forString(String) method is used with the indication. To make it short, it's the same as calling forString(String) with the name of your field as parameter. Note: this require the argument -parameters in your compiler to allow reflection to find the name of your parameters.
        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of argument needed.
        Parameters:
        clazz - The target class.
        indication - The name of the argument in case of ambiguity.
        Returns:
        The Argument that matches the best for the given inputs.
        Throws:
        InvalidCommandPatternMethodException - If there is too much ambiguity or if there is no match.
